topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5386a7d263687216d64f0200#post_5386a7d263687216d64f0200
The Mauser C96 is actually of German origin. It's just that the Chinese copied and used them extensively during the first half of the 20th century that it achieved a cult status. There are rare variations made in the Shaanxi province that were chambered in .45acp.


"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5386aafa636872166cbe0300#post_5386aafa636872166cbe0300
The C96 was originally chambered in 7.63Ã—25mm Mauser. The Red9 was a variation produced for WW1 German troops to be chambered in the 9mm Luger, to be used alongside the then standard issue Luger pistol.

topics.body:
On the contrary to popular belief and Hollywood/VG depictions. The Luger wasn't the standard issue side arm of Germany in WW2. They were used, but were mostly issued to high ranking rear echelon personnel, as the Luger sucked in dirty battlefield terrains and were expensive to produce.

The Walther P38
!https://www.impactguns.com/data/default/images/catalog/535/p38_813393013621.jpg!
was the standard issue. It was well known to be the first *double-action*/single-action lock-breach military pistols to be fielded to war.
